content: The "Bring Jobs Home Act" is a new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing a credit for insourcing expenses. The "Bring Jobs Home Act" added a new section to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, offering a 20% credit for eligible insourcing expenses incurred by a taxpayer in connection with eliminating or establishing a business unit outside the United States. The "Bring Jobs Home Act" provides a 20% credit for eligible insourcing expenses incurred by a taxpayer in connection with relocating a business unit within the United States. Eligible expenses include deductions under section 162 and other related costs like permit fees and equipment installation. The term 'business unit' refers to any trade or business or line of business within a trade or business. An 'expanded affiliated group' is defined as an affiliated group with more than 50 percent ownership, excluding certain entities like partnerships. The text discusses the criteria for an entity to be considered part of an expanded affiliated group, including control by group members. It also outlines that expenses must be incurred as part of a relocation plan and excludes operating expenses from consideration. Additionally, it mentions an increased domestic employment requirement for a specific credit. The text outlines an increased domestic employment requirement for claiming a credit, stating that the number of full-time equivalent employees must exceed the previous year's count. It also mentions that all employers treated as a single entity under specific sections will be considered as one for this requirement. The text discusses the eligibility criteria for claiming a credit based on insourcing expenses, specifying that these expenses must be accounted for in the taxable year following the completion of the insourcing plan. Additionally, there is an option to apply an employment test and claim the credit in the first full taxable year after the plan is completed.
